entry.et: Middle English, from Old English hīgid, hīd

def.dt: :any of various old English units of land area

entry.et: Middle English hiden, from Old English hȳdan; akin to Greek keuthein to conceal

def.dt: :to screen from or as if from view :obscure
:to turn (the eyes or face) away in shame or anger
:to remain out of sight often used with out

entry.pt: hide conceal screen secrete bury mean to withhold or withdraw from sight. hide may or may not suggest intent hide in the closet a house hidden in the woods. conceal usually does imply intent and often specifically implies a refusal to divulge concealed the weapon. screen implies an interposing of something that prevents discovery a house screened by trees. secrete suggests a depositing in a place unknown to others secreted the amulet inside his shirt. bury implies covering up so as to hide completely buried the treasure.

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English hȳd; akin to Old High German hūt hide, Latin cutis skin, Greek kytos hollow vessel

def.dt: :the skin of an animal whether raw or dressed used especially of large heavy skins
:the life or physical well-being of a person betrayed his friend to save his own hide
:a vestige or trace of someone or something a wife he hadn't seen hide or hair of in over 20 years H. L. Davis
:a children's game in which one player does not look while others hide and then goes to find them
